title: 109_hr4015
content: The "Milk Regulatory Equity Act of 2005" is also known as the Milk Regulatory Equity Act. It aims to establish equity in milk regulations. The "Milk Regulatory Equity Act of 2005" establishes minimum milk prices for handlers, subjecting them to federal milk marketing order requirements for packaged fluid milk products. The "Milk Regulatory Equity Act of 2005" requires handlers of Class I milk products operating within Federal order milk marketing areas to pay minimum prices for raw milk purchases. This applies to handlers with packaged fluid milk product route dispositions or sales in states mandating minimum prices for raw milk. The "Milk Regulatory Equity Act of 2005" mandates that handlers of Class I milk products in Federal order milk marketing areas must pay minimum prices for raw milk purchases, unless exempted as specified. The Milk Regulatory Equity Act of 2005 requires handlers of Class I milk products in Federal order milk marketing areas to pay minimum prices for raw milk purchases, unless exempted. Exemptions include nonpool plants, producer-handlers with low sales, and handlers with low quantities of received milk products. The Milk Regulatory Equity Act of 2005 requires handlers of Class I milk products in Federal order milk marketing areas to pay minimum prices for raw milk purchases, unless exempted. Exemptions include nonpool plants, producer-handlers with low sales, and handlers with low quantities of received milk products. Handlers with distribution of Class I milk products in specific marketing areas are not exempt from minimum price requirements. The Milk Regulatory Equity Act of 2005 allows handlers to be exempt from minimum price requirements if their own farm production of Class I products exceeds 3,000,000 pounds. Nevada is excluded from federal milk marketing orders. Records and facility requirements are still applicable despite the exemptions. The Milk Regulatory Equity Act of 2005 exempts milk handlers from minimum price requirements if their farm production of Class I products exceeds 3,000,000 pounds. Handlers subject to regulation must comply with section 1000.27 of title 7, Code of Federal Regulations. The amendments made by this section take effect more than 15 days after the enactment of the Act, with the Secretary of Agriculture expediting implementation through Federal milk marketing orders. The Agriculture Adjustment Act, reenacted with amendments by the Agriculture Marketing Agreement Act of 1937, regulates handlers based on the location of their distributing plant. These amendments are not subject to a referendum.
